title: Interface Concepts
description: A collection of questions assessing understanding of interface purposes and usability principles

questions.title: Interface Purpose
questions.prompt: A student uses the school's online portal to check their timetable and see their NCEA results. What is the main purpose of this interface?

options.text: To allow students to access and view their personal academic information.
To make the school's website look modern and professional.
To reduce the number of teachers in the school.
To provide a platform for downloading software updates.

questions.explanation: The correct answer directly describes what the user achieves with the interface, which is the core of defining its purpose. Other options are incorrect or secondary effects.

questions.title: Identify Usability Principle
questions.prompt: On a pizza delivery website, the 'Checkout' button is always green and located in the top-right corner on every page. Which usability principle does this best demonstrate?
questions.explanation: Using the same design and placement for a specific function (like the Checkout button) throughout a single website is a clear example of internal consistency, which helps users learn the interface quickly.

questions.title: Explain Usability Principle
questions.prompt: A banking app shows a confirmation screen before transferring money, stating 'You are about to transfer $500 to John Smith. Is this correct?' Why is this confirmation important?

options.text: It makes the app look more professional
It prevents users from making costly errors
It slows down the transaction process
It reduces the amount of text on screen

questions.explanation: Confirmation screens are a key example of error prevention - they give users a chance to review and correct their actions before committing to potentially irreversible or costly operations.
